bestBHT.bht: Claiming a loftier Sonship by distancing Himself from human messengers, our Lord emphasizes the guilt associated with disregarding His well-beloved Son. The phrase it may be conveys a strong probability of redemption and highlights the significant chance for a reverential response. This expectation of reverence is underscored in all three Gospel accounts. The owner's dilemma, found only in Luke's narrative, signifies the urgency for a solution. By sending his beloved Son, the owner hopes for the people to demonstrate the reverence he seeks.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Having yet therefore one son, his well-beloved" - our Lord thus severing Himself from all merely human messengers, and claiming Sonship in its loftiest sense.
Surely" - implying the almost unimaginable guilt of not doing so.
Marvin Vincent: It may be [ισως]. Only here in New Testament. The adverb of isov, equal. It expresses more than perhaps, implying rather a strong probability. Compare the phrase, it is an even chance that.
Archibald T. Robertson: What shall I do?" (Τ ποιησω;). Deliberative future indicative or aorist subjunctive (same form). This detail only in Luke.
All three have 'will reverence' (εντραπησοντα) for which see Matthew and Mark.
It may be (ισως). Perhaps, from ισος, equal. Old adverb, but only here in the N.T.
John Gill: what can be done more than has been done?
I will send my beloved Son
it may be they will reverence him, when they see him

bhtAttempts.bht: Having only one beloved son, the Lord separates Himself from all human messengers and establishes His highest claim of Sonship. The guilt of not recognizing Him as such is almost unimaginable. The phrase it may be implies a strong probability, suggesting that there is a significant chance of redemption. The reverential response that is expected is emphasized in all three Gospel accounts. The question raised by the owner reflects on the desperation of the situation and the need for a solution. This deliberation is only found in Luke's account. Ultimately, the owner's hope lies in sending his beloved Son, hoping that the people will show reverence when they encounter Him.

With only one well-beloved son, our Lord distances Himself from human messengers, asserting His unique and supreme Sonship. The phrase it may be expresses a strong probability, suggesting the potential for redemption. The expectation of reverence is emphasized in all three Gospel accounts. The owner's deliberation, found only in Luke's narrative, signifies the urgency for a solution. In sending his beloved Son, the owner hopes for a reverential response from the people.

With His well-beloved Son as the singular messenger, our Lord establishes His elevated Sonship, distinct from human agents. The phrase it may be conveys a powerful likelihood of redemption. The expectation of reverence is strongly emphasized across all three Gospels. The owner's deliberation, unique to Luke's account, highlights the urgency to find a resolution. The owner's hope lies in the sending of his beloved Son, in anticipation of the people revering Him upon His appearance.

Elevating Himself above mere human messengers, our Lord claims a distinct Sonship with His well-beloved Son. The phrase it may be suggests a strong probability for redemption. The expectation of reverence is reiterated in all three Gospel accounts. The owner's deliberation, exclusive to Luke, highlights the urgency for a solution. By sending his beloved Son, the owner hopes to elicit a reverential response from the people.

Claiming a loftier Sonship by distancing Himself from human messengers, our Lord emphasizes the guilt associated with disregarding His well-beloved Son. The phrase it may be conveys a strong probability of redemption and highlights the significant chance for a reverential response. This expectation of reverence is underscored in all three Gospel accounts. The owner's dilemma, found only in Luke's narrative, signifies the urgency for a solution. By sending his beloved Son, the owner hopes for the people to demonstrate the reverence he seeks.
